seg.seg: ... that (girl) says: The queen of the Śākyas Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī has sent (me)
(to ask when the Buddha-god the teacher) will come (from the city of Śrāvastī) to the city of Kapilavastu. The Śākya men are, as it were, crowded by Śākya women, ...
... I have got the opportunity (to ask) whether at the Nyagrodhārāma monastery, he, Mahānāman (by name), (might) now ...
the lay-women worship the Vihāras. Having seen ..., Muktikā says: ||
(Paṭṭinī) says: I come here to ask about the coming of the Buddha-god the teacher, when he (is about to come).
(Paṭṭi)nī says: With great efforts on the part of the Śākya queen Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī,
(a cloth) has come into existence. Therefore she now keeps asking when the Buddha-god, the teacher is about to arrive.
The Śākya queen Gautamī, ... noblest among women, among the skills however weaving is the lowiest of all.
Why then did she care to do that? 1 || Paṭṭinī says: If it was only a matter of weaving ...,
(Muktikā says:) Besides this, (what) did she do? Paṭṭinī says: || In the Aptsaradarśaṃ [tune] || She herself with her own (hands), ...
she made (them) grow with boiled milk, she herself gathered them; she herself did the carding, and she herself indeed ...
she (herself) indeed wove the excellent cotton sheet. 1 || The lay-woman says: Very clearly, (from) the Buddha-god (the teacher), I, ...
formerly (she [Gautamī] worshipped) the Buddha Vipaśyin with perfumed ﬂower, with food and drink, properly [and] piously.
she became the foster mother of Buddha-god the teacher. Always ... (was) of a sixteen years old girl.
What (is) the reason now that the queen of the Śākyas herself planted the cotton, [and] herself ...
What is the reason now that the queen of the Śākyas has sown the cotton just by herself? (cf 147)
it shines among ... of the Śākyas, it is not despicable. Look, noble one ...

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 1a4-2a1. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 148.
The agreement between the Tocharian and the Uyghur text in the ﬁrst lines is not very close.
acle is a new form of uncertain meaning.
In the Uyghur text, the name of the lay-woman (upāsikā-) is not given until MaitrHami 3, 4 a12.
The girl Paṭṭinī is now speaking. Starting from here, the agreement between the Tocharian and the Uyghur text (MaitrHami 3, 1 a15ff.) is closer.
The form corresponding to TB wapāttsa should be TA. wāpats*, the abstract of which would be wāptsune*. Therefore, wāpäṃtsune must be derived from wāpaṃts*, which may be the term for female weaver.
kulewāsaṃ is the first word of a stanza of the type 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables.
aptsaradarśnaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 14 (7/7) syllables.
Uyghur upasanč (in the corresponding line and elsewhere) shows a partial resanskritization of a TA wāskāñc, corresponding to Skt. upāsikā- ‘lay-woman’.
The reading ttā appears to be preferable to ntā: the onset tt- remains unexplained.
